intro: Smilax chiapensis, commonly known as the Chiapan devil's backbone, is a climbing shrub native to Central America and parts of Mexico. It belongs to the family Araceae and is characterized by its woody stems and spiny projections. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in spadices, typical of the arum family. Its leaves are usually alternate, simple, and have a rough, textured surface. Smilax chiapensis is often found in humid, shaded environments within tropical and subtropical forests.
